1.verse_text: The vision of [the prophet] Isaiah the son of Amoz concerning [the kingdom of] Judah and [its capital] Jerusalem, which he saw [as revealed by God] during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah. For the L ord has spoken: “I have reared and brought up sons, But they have rebelled against Me and have broken away. And the donkey its master’s feeding trough, But Israel does not know [Me as L ord ], My people do not understand.” A people loaded down with wickedness [with sin, with injustice, with wrongdoing], Offspring of evildoers, Sons who behave corruptly! They have abandoned (rejected) the L ord , They have despised the Holy One of Israel [provoking Him to anger], They have turned away from Him. You [only] continue to rebel. The whole head is sick And the whole heart is faint and sick. There is nothing healthy in the nation’s body, Only bruises, welts, and raw wounds, Not pressed out or bandaged, Nor softened with oil [as a remedy]. Your cities are burned with fire, Your fields—strangers are devouring them in your very presence; It is desolate, as overthrown by strangers. Like a watchman’s hut in a cucumber field, like a besieged city [isolated, surrounded by devastation]. Had not left us a few survivors, We would be like Sodom, We would be like Gomorrah. You rulers of [another] Sodom, Listen to the law and instruction of our God, You people of [another] Gomorrah. Says the L ord . “I have had enough of [your] burnt offerings of rams And the fat of well-fed cattle [without your obedience]; And I take no pleasure in the blood of bulls or lambs or goats [offered without repentance]. Who requires this of you, this trampling of My [temple] courts [by your sinful feet]? [Your] incense is repulsive to Me; [Your] New Moon and Sabbath [observances], the calling of assemblies— I cannot endure wickedness [your sin, your injustice, your wrongdoing] and [the squalor of] the festive assembly. They have become a burden to Me; I am weary of bearing them. I will hide My eyes from you; Yes, even though you offer many prayers, I will not be listening. Your hands are full of blood! Get your evil deeds out of My sight. Stop doing evil, Seek justice, Rebuke the ruthless, Defend the fatherless, Plead for the [rights of the] widow [in court]. Says the L ord . They shall be as white as snow; Though they are red like crimson, They shall be like wool. You shall eat the best of the land; You shall be devoured by the sword.” For the mouth of the L ord has spoken. She who was full of justice! Right standing with God once lodged in her, But now murderers. Your wine is diluted with water. And companions of thieves; Everyone loves bribes And chases after gifts. They do not defend the fatherless, Nor does the widow’s cause come before them [instead they delay or turn a deaf ear]. The Mighty One of Israel, declares: “Ah, I will be freed of My adversaries And avenge Myself on My enemies. And will [thoroughly] purge away your dross as with lye And remove all your tin (impurity). And your counselors as at the beginning; Afterward you will be called the city of righteousness, The faithful city.” And her repentant ones with righteousness. And those who abandon (turn away from) the L ord will be consumed (perish). And you will be ashamed of the gardens [of passion] which you have chosen [for pagan worship]. And like a garden that has no water. And his work a spark. So both will burn together And there will be none to quench them.
Hear, O heavens, and listen, O earth;
The ox [instinctively] knows its owner,
Ah, sinful nation,
Why should you be stricken and punished again [since no change results from it]?
From the sole of the foot even to the head
Your land lies desolate [because of your disobedience],
The Daughter of Zion (Jerusalem) is left like a [deserted] shelter in a vineyard,
If the L ord of hosts
Hear the word of the L ord [rulers of Jerusalem],
“What are your multiplied sacrifices to Me [without your repentance]?”
When you come to appear before Me,
Do not bring worthless offerings again,
I hate [the hypocrisy of] your New Moon festivals and your appointed feasts.
So when you spread out your hands [in prayer, pleading for My help],
“Wash yourselves, make yourselves clean;
Learn to do good.
“Come now, and let us reason together,” “ Though your sins are like scarlet,
If you are willing and obedient,
But if you refuse and rebel,
How the faithful city has become a prostitute [idolatrous, despicable],
Your silver has turned to lead,
Your rulers are rebels
Therefore the Lord G od of hosts,
And I will turn My hand against you,
Then I will restore your judges as at the first,
Zion will be redeemed with justice
But rebels and sinners will be crushed and destroyed together,
For you will be ashamed [of the degradation] of the oaks in which you took [idolatrous] pleasure,
For you will be like an oak whose leaf withers and dies
The strong man will become tinder,

2.verse_text: The word [from God] which Isaiah son of Amoz saw [in a vision] concerning [the nation of] Judah and [its capital city] Jerusalem. In the last days The mountain of the house of the L ord And will be exalted above the hills; And all the nations will stream to it. “Come, let us go up to the mountain of the L ord , To the house (temple) of the God of Jacob; That He may teach us His ways And that we may walk in His paths.” For the law will go out from Zion And the word of the L ord from Jerusalem. And will mediate [disputes] for many peoples; And they will beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation will not lift up the sword against nation, And never again will they learn war. Because they are filled with influences from the east, And they are soothsayers [who foretell] like the Philistines; Also they strike bargains with the children of foreigners (pagans). And there is no end to their treasures; Their land has also been filled with horses And there is no end to their chariots. They worship the work of their hands, That which their own fingers have made. And the man of importance has been degraded, Therefore do not forgive them [O L ord ]. From the terror of the L ord and from the splendor of His majesty. And the arrogance of men will be humbled, And the L ord alone will be exalted in that day. Against all who are proud and arrogant And against all who are lifted up, That they may be degraded. Against all the oaks of Bashan [east of the Jordan], Against all the hills that are lifted up, Against every fortified wall, And against all the beautiful craft. And the arrogance of men will be degraded; The L ord alone shall be exalted in that day, And into the holes of the ground [fleeing] From the terror and dread of the L ord And from the splendor of His majesty, When He arises to terrify the earth. Their idols of silver and their idols of gold, Which they made for themselves [as objects] to worship, From the terror and dread of the L ord and the splendor of His majesty, When He arises to terrify the earth. For why should he be esteemed?
Now it will come to pass that Will be [firmly] established as the highest of the mountains,
And many peoples shall come and say,
And He will judge between the nations,
O house of Jacob, come, let us walk in the light of the L ord .
Most certainly [L ord ] You have abandoned your people, the house of Jacob,
Their land has also been filled with silver and gold
Their land has also been filled with idols;
So the common man has been humbled [before idols]
Go among the rocks and hide in the dust
The proud look of man will be degraded
For the L ord of hosts will have a day of reckoning
And the wrath of God will be against all the cedars of Lebanon [west of the Jordan] that are high and lifted up,
Against all the high mountains,
Against every high tower,
Against all the ships of Tarshish
Then the pride of man will be humbled
And the idols will completely vanish (be abolished).
They [the stricken, deprived of all in which they had trusted] will go into the caves of the rocks
In that day men will throw away to the moles and to the bats
To go into the caverns of the rocks and into the clefts of the [ragged] cliffs [as they flee]
Stop regarding man, whose breath [of life] is in his nostrils [for so little time];

3.verse_text: Listen carefully, the Lord G od of hosts is removing from Jerusalem and from Judah Both supply and support, the whole supply of bread And the whole supply of water; The judge and the prophet, The diviner and the elder, The counselor and the expert artisan, And the skillful enchanter. And capricious (impulsive, unpredictable) children will rule over them. Each one by another, and each one by his neighbor; The boy will be arrogant and insolent toward the elder And the vulgar (common) toward the honorable [person of rank]. “You have a robe, you shall be our judge and ruler, And this pile of ruins will be under your control,” For in my house there is neither bread nor clothing; You should not make me a judge and ruler of the people.” Because their words and their actions are against the L ord , To rebel against His glorious presence and defiantly provoke Him. They display their sin like Sodom; They do not even hide it. For they have brought evil on themselves [as a reward]. For they will eat the fruit of their [righteous] actions. For what his hand has done shall be done to him. And women rule over them. O My people! Your leaders lead you astray And confuse (destroy, swallow up) the direction of your paths. And stands to judge the people. “For it is you who have devoured the vineyard [with your oppression, you have robbed the people and ruined the country]; The plunder of the poor is in your houses. And grinding the face of the poor?” Declares the Lord G od of hosts. And walk with outstretched necks and seductive (flirtatious, alluring) eyes, And trip along with mincing steps and an affected gait And the L ord will expose their foreheads (send them into captivity).” Instead of a belt, a rope; Instead of well-set hair, baldness; Instead of fine clothes, a robe of sackcloth; And branding [of captives by the scorching heat] instead of beauty. And your mighty men in battle. And she, being ruined and desolate, will sit upon the ground.
The brave man and the warrior [He is also removing],
The captain of fifty and the man of honor,
And I will make mere boys their princes,
And the people will be oppressed,
When a man takes hold of his brother in the house of his father, saying,
He will protest on that day, saying, “I will not be a governor; Woe (judgment is coming) to them! And walk with jingling anklets on their feet,
For Jerusalem has stumbled and Judah has fallen,
Their partiality testifies against them,
Say to the righteous that it will go well with them,
Woe (judgment is coming) to the wicked! It shall go badly with him,
O My people! Children are their oppressors,
The L ord rises to contend,
The L ord enters into judgment with the elders of His people and their princes,
What do you mean by crushing My people
Moreover, the L ord said, “Because the daughters of Zion are proud
Therefore the Lord will afflict the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion with scabs [making them bald],
In that day the Lord will take away the beauty of their anklets, [braided] caps, crescent [head] ornaments,
dangling earrings, bracelets, and the hanging veils and scarves,
head wraps (turbans), [short, jingling] ankle chains, sashes, perfume boxes, amulets (charms),
signet [finger] rings, nose rings,
festival robes, outer tunics, shawls, handbags,
hand mirrors, [fine linen] undergarments, headbands, and veils [covering the entire body].
Now it will come to pass that instead of the sweet fragrance of spices there will be [the stench of] rottenness;
Your men will fall by the sword
And Jerusalem’s gates will lament (cry out in grief) and mourn [as those who wail for the dead];

4.verse_text: And in that day seven women will take hold of one man, saying, “We will eat our own food and wear [and provide] our own clothes; only let us be called by your name; take away our shame [of being unmarried].”
In that day the Branch of the L ord will be splendid and glorious, and the fruit of the land will be excellent and lovely to those of Israel who have survived.
It will come to pass that he who is left in Zion and remains in Jerusalem will be called holy (set apart for God)—everyone who is recorded for [eternal] life in Jerusalem.
When the Lord has washed away the [moral] filth of the daughters of Zion and has cleansed the bloodstains of Jerusalem from her midst, by the spirit of judgment and by the spirit of burning,

then the L ord will create over the entire site of Mount Zion and over her assemblies, a cloud by day, smoke, and the brightness of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory and brilliance will be a canopy [a defense, a covering of His divine love and protection].
And there will be a pavilion for shade from the heat by day, and a refuge and a shelter from the storm and the rain.

5.verse_text: Now let me sing for my greatly Beloved [L ord ] A song of my Beloved about His vineyard (His chosen people). My greatly Beloved had a vineyard on a very fertile slope (the promised land, Canaan). And He built a tower in the center of it; Then He expected it to produce [the choicest] grapes, But it produced only worthless ones. Judge between Me and My vineyard (My people). When I expected it to produce good grapes, why did it yield worthless ones? I will take away its thorn-hedge, and it will be burned up; It will not be pruned or cultivated, But briars and thorns will come up. I will also command the clouds not to rain on it.” And the men of Judah are His delightful planting [which He loves]. So He looked for justice, but in fact, [He saw] bloodshed and lawlessness; [He looked] for righteousness, but in fact, [He heard] a cry of distress and oppression. Until there is no more room [for others], So that you have to live alone in the midst of the land! Even great and beautiful ones will be unoccupied. Who stay up late in the night till wine inflames them! But they do not regard nor even pay attention to the deeds of the L ord , Nor do they consider the work of His hands. And their honorable men are famished, And their common people are parched with thirst. And the eyes of the proud (arrogant) will be degraded. And God, the Holy One, will show Himself holy in righteousness [through His righteous judgments]. And strangers will eat in the desolate places of the [exiled] wealthy. And sin as if with cart ropes [towing their own punishment]; And let the purpose of the Holy One of Israel approach And come to pass, so that we may know it!” Who substitute darkness for light and light for darkness; Who substitute bitter for sweet and sweet for bitter! And clever and shrewd in their own sight! And men of strength in mixing intoxicating drinks, And take away the rights of those who are in the right! And the dry grass collapses into the flame, So their root will become like rot and their blossom blow away like fine dust; Because they have rejected the law of the L ord of hosts And despised and discarded the word of the Holy One of Israel. And He has stretched out His hand against them and has struck them down. And the mountains trembled, and their dead bodies lay like rubbish in the middle of the streets. In spite of all this God’s anger is not turned away, But His hand is still stretched out [in judgment]. And will whistle for them from the ends of the earth; And indeed, they will come with great speed swiftly. No one slumbers or sleeps; Nor is the belt at their waist undone [as if unprepared for action], Nor is the strap of their sandal broken. Their horses’ hoofs seem like flint and their chariot wheels like a whirlwind. They growl and seize their prey And carry it off and there is no one to save it. And if one looks to the land, in fact, there is darkness and distress; Even the light will be darkened by its clouds.

He dug it all around and cleared away its stones, And planted it with the choicest vine (the people of Judah). And also hewed out a wine vat in it. I will break down its stone wall and it will be trampled down [by enemies]. And a homer ( six bushels) of seed will produce [only] one ephah of grain.” And Jerusalem’s splendor, her multitude, her [boisterous] uproar and her [drunken] revelers descend into it.
“And now, says the L ord , O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah,
What more could have been done for My vineyard that I have not done in it?
So now let me tell you what I am going to do to My vineyard:
I will turn it into a wasteland;
For the vineyard of the L ord of hosts is the house (nation) of Israel
Woe (judgment is coming) to those who join house to house and join field to field [to increase their holdings by depriving others],
In my ears the L ord of hosts said, “Be assured that many houses will become desolate,
For ten acres of vineyard will yield [only] one bath of wine ,
Woe (judgment is coming) to those who rise early in the morning to pursue intoxicating drink,
They have lyre and harp, tambourine and flute, and wine at their feasts;
Therefore My people go into exile because they lack knowledge [of God];
Therefore Sheol (the realm of the dead) has increased its appetite and opened its mouth beyond measure;
So the common man will be bowed down and the man of importance degraded,
But the L ord of hosts will be exalted in justice,
Then the lambs will graze [among the ruins] as in their own pasture,
Woe (judgment is coming) to those who drag along wickedness with cords of falsehood,
Who say, “Let Him move speedily, let Him expedite His work [His promised vengeance], so that we may see it;
Woe (judgment is coming) to those who call evil good, and good evil;
Woe (judgment is coming) to those who are wise in their own eyes
Woe (judgment is coming) to those who are heroes at drinking wine
Who justify the wicked and acquit the guilty for a bribe,
Therefore, as the tongue of fire consumes the stubble [from straw]
Therefore the anger of the L ord has burned against His people,
He will lift up a flag to [call] the distant nations [to bring His judgment on Judah],
No one among them is weary or stumbles,
Their arrows are sharp and all their bows are strung and bent;
Their roaring is like a lioness, they roar like young lions;
And in that day they will roar against them (Judah) like the roaring of the sea.

6.verse_text: In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw [in a vision] the Lord sitting on a throne, high and exalted, with the train of His royal robe filling the [most holy part of the] temple.
Above Him seraphim (heavenly beings) stood; each one had six wings: with two wings he covered his face, with two wings he covered his feet, and with two wings he flew.

And one called out to another, saying, “Holy, Holy, Holy is the L ord of hosts; The whole earth is filled with His glory.” “Woe is me! For I am ruined, Because I am a man of [ceremonially] unclean lips, And I live among a people of unclean lips; For my eyes have seen the King, the L ord of hosts.” ‘Keep on listening, but do not understand; Keep on looking, but do not comprehend.’ Their ears dull, And their eyes dim, Otherwise they might see with their eyes, Hear with their ears, Understand with their hearts, And return and be healed.” “Until cities are devastated and without inhabitant, And houses are without people And the land is utterly desolate, And there are many deserted places in the midst of the land. It will again be subject to destruction [consumed and burned], Like a massive terebinth tree or like an oak Whose stump remains when it is chopped down. The holy seed [the elect remnant] is its stump [the substance of Israel].”
And the foundations of the thresholds trembled at the voice of him who called out, and the temple was filling with smoke.
Then one of the seraphim flew to me with a burning coal in his hand, which he had taken from the altar with tongs.
He touched my mouth with it and said, “Listen carefully, this has touched your lips; your wickedness [your sin, your injustice, your wrongdoing] is taken away and your sin atoned for and forgiven.”
Then I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for Us?” Then I said, “Here am I. Send me!”
And He said, “Go, and tell this people:
Make the heart of this people insensitive,
Then I said, “Lord, how long?” And He answered,
The L ord has removed [His] people far away,
And though a tenth [of the people] remain in the land,

7.verse_text: Now it came to pass in the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin king of Aram (Syria) and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to Jerusalem to wage war against it, but they could not conquer it.
When the house of David (Judah) was told, “Aram is allied with Ephraim (Israel),” the hearts of Ahaz and his people trembled as the trees of the forest tremble in the wind.
Then the L ord said to Isaiah, “Go out to meet Ahaz [king of Judah], you and your son Shear-jashub, at the end of the aqueduct of the Upper Pool, on the highway to the Fuller’s Field;

and say to him, ‘Take care and be calm, do not fear and be weak-hearted because of these two stumps of smoldering logs, on account of the fierce anger of [King] Rezin and Aram and of the son of Remaliah (Pekah, usurper of the throne of Israel).
Because Aram, along with Ephraim (Israel) and the son of Remaliah, have planned evil against you (Judah), saying,
“Let us go up against Judah and terrorize it; and let us breach its wall and tear it apart [each of us taking a portion] and set up the son of Tabeel over it as its [puppet] king,”
for this is what the Lord G od says, “It shall not stand nor shall it happen.
For the head (capital) of Aram is Damascus and the head of Damascus is [King] Rezin (now within sixty-five years Ephraim will be broken to pieces and will no longer be a people).

And the head (capital) of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is Remaliah’s son [King Pekah]. If you will not believe [and trust in God and His message], be assured that you will not be established.” ’ ”
Then the L ord spoke again to [King] Ahaz, saying,
“Ask a sign for yourself from the L ord your God [one that will convince you that God has spoken and will keep His word]; make your request as deep as Sheol or as high as heaven.”
But Ahaz said, “ I will not ask, nor will I test the L ord !”
Then Isaiah said, “Hear then, O house of David! Is it too small a thing for you to try the patience of men, but will you try the patience of my God as well?
Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Listen carefully, the virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and she will call his name Immanuel (God with us).
He will eat curds and honey when he knows enough to refuse evil and choose good.
For before the child will know enough to refuse evil and choose good, the land (Canaan) whose two kings you dread will be deserted [both Ephraim and Aram].

The L ord will bring on you, on your people, and on your father’s house such days as have not come since the day that Ephraim (the ten northern tribes) separated from Judah—[He will call for] the king of Assyria.”
In that day the L ord will whistle for the fly that is in the mouth of the rivers and canals of Egypt and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
These [armies, like flies and bees] will all come and settle on the steep and rugged ravines and in the clefts of the rocks, and on all the thorn bushes and in all the watering places.

In that day [when foreign armies swarm the land] the Lord will shave with a razor, hired from the regions beyond the Euphrates ( that is, with the king of Assyria), [that razor will shave] the head and the hair of the legs; and it will also remove the beard [leaving Judah stripped, shamed and scorned].
Now in that day [because of the poverty caused by the invaders] a man will keep alive only a young milk cow and two sheep;
and because of the abundance of milk produced he will eat curds, for everyone that is left in the land will eat [only] curds and [wild] honey.
And it will come to pass in that day, in every place where there used to be a thousand vines, worth a thousand silver shekels, there will be briars and thorns.
People will come there [to hunt] with arrows and with bows because all the land will be briars and thorns.

As for all the hills which used to be cultivated with the pick and the hoe, you will no longer go there for fear of briars and thorns; but they will become a place where oxen are pastured and where sheep tread.

8.verse_text: Then the L ord said to me, “Take for yourself a large tablet [for public display] and write on it in ordinary characters: Belonging to Maher-shalal-hash-baz.
And I will get faithful witnesses to attest [to this prophecy] for me, Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.”
So I approached [my wife] the prophetess, and she conceived and gave birth to a son. Then the L ord said to me, “Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz [to remind the people of the prophecy];

for before the boy knows how to say, ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the riches of Damascus (Aram’s capital) and the spoil of Samaria (Israel’s capital) will be carried away by the king of Assyria.” And rejoice in Rezin [the king of Aram] and Remaliah’s son [Pekah the king of Israel], The king of Assyria and all his glory; And it will rise over all its channels and canals and go far beyond its banks. Reaching even to the neck [of which Jerusalem is the head], And its outstretched wings (the armies of Assyria) will fill the width of Your land, O Immanuel. Listen, all you [our enemies from the] far countries. Prepare yourselves [for war], and be shattered; Prepare yourselves [for war], and be shattered. Speak the word, but it will not stand, For God is with us (Immanuel).” In regard to all that this people call a conspiracy, And you are not to fear what they fear nor be in dread of it. He shall be your [source of] fear, He shall be your [source of] dread [not man]. But to both the houses of Israel [both the northern and southern kingdoms—Israel and Judah, He will be] a stone on which to stumble and a rock on which to trip, A trap and a snare for the inhabitants of Jerusalem. Then they will fall and be broken, They will even be snared and trapped.”
Again the L ord spoke to me, saying,
“Because these people (Judah) have refused the gently flowing waters of Shiloah
Now therefore, listen carefully, the Lord is about to bring on them the waters of the [Euphrates] River, strong and abundant—
Then it will sweep on into Judah; it will overflow and pass through [the hills],
“Be broken [in pieces], O peoples, and be shattered!
Take counsel together [against Judah], but it will come to nothing;
For in this way the L ord spoke to me with His strong hand [upon me] and instructed me not to walk in the way of this people [behaving as they do], saying,
“You are not to say, ‘It is a conspiracy!’
It is the L ord of hosts whom you are to regard as holy and awesome.
Then He shall be a sanctuary [a sacred, indestructible shelter for those who fear and trust Him];
Many [among them] will stumble over them;
Bind up the testimony, seal the law and the teaching among my (Isaiah’s) disciples.
And I will wait for the L ord who is hiding His face from the house of Jacob; and I will look eagerly for Him.
Listen carefully, I and the children whom the L ord has given me are for signs and wonders [that will occur] in Israel from the L ord of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.

When the people [instead of trusting God] say to you, “Consult the mediums [who try to talk to the dead] and the soothsayers who chirp and whisper and mutter,” should not a people consult their God? Should they consult the dead on behalf of the living?
[Direct those people] to the law and to the testimony! If their teachings are not in accord with this word, it is because they have no dawn.

They [who consult mediums and soothsayers] will pass through the land deeply distressed and hungry, and when they are hungry, they will become enraged and will curse their king and their God as they look upward.
Then they will look to the earth, they will see only distress and darkness, the gloom of anguish; and they will be driven away into darkness and overwhelming night.

9.verse_text: But there will be no more gloom for her who was in anguish [for with judgment comes the promise of salvation]. In earlier times He treated the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali with contempt, but later on He will make them honored [by the presence of the Messiah], by the way of the sea, on the other side of Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles. Those who live in the dark land, The Light will shine on them. You will multiply their joy; They will rejoice before You Like the joy and jubilation of the harvest, As men rejoice when they divide the spoil [of victory]. And [every soldier’s] garment rolled in blood, will be used for burning, fuel for the fire. And the government shall be upon His shoulder, And His name shall be called Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God, Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace. [He shall rule] on the throne of David and over his kingdom, To establish it and to uphold it with justice and righteousness From that time forward and forevermore. The zeal of the L ord of hosts will accomplish this. And it falls on Israel [the ten northern tribes, the kingdom of Ephraim]. Who say in pride and arrogance of heart: But we will rebuild [all the better] with ashlar (hewed stones); The sycamores have been cut down, But we will replace them with [expensive] cedars.” And spurs their enemies on, And they devour Israel with gaping jaws. In spite of all this, God’s anger does not turn away But His hand is still stretched out [in judgment]. Nor do they seek the L ord of hosts [as their most essential need]. Both [the high] palm branch and [the low] bulrush in one day. And the prophet who teaches lies, he is the tail. And those who are led [astray] by them are swallowed up. Nor does He have compassion on their fatherless or their widows; For every one of them is godless and an evildoer, And every mouth is speaking foolishness. In spite of all this, God’s anger does not turn away But His hand is still stretched out [in judgment]. It consumes briars and thorns, It even sets the forest thickets ablaze; And it swirls upward in a column of smoke. And the people are like fuel for the fire; No man spares his brother. And they eat what is on the left hand but they are not satisfied; Each eats the flesh of his own arm. And together they are against Judah (the southern kingdom, the house of David). In spite of all this, God’s anger does not turn away But His hand is still stretched out [in judgment].
The people who walk in [spiritual] darkness Will see a great Light; The rod of their oppressor, as at the battle of Midian. That is, Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria [its capital],
You [O God] will increase the nation,
For You will break the yoke of Israel’s burden and the staff (goad) on their shoulders,
For every boot of the marching warrior in the battle tumult,
For to us a Child shall be born, to us a Son shall be given;
There shall be no end to the increase of His government and of peace,
The Lord sends a word (message) against Jacob,
And all the people know it,
“The bricks have fallen down,
Therefore the L ord raises against Ephraim adversaries from Rezin [king of Aram]
The Arameans on the east and the Philistines on the west;
Yet the people do not turn back [in repentance] to Him who struck them,
Therefore the L ord cuts off head and tail [the highest and the lowest] from Israel,
The elderly and honorable man, he is the head;
For those who lead this people are causing them to go astray;
Therefore the Lord does not rejoice over their young men,
For wickedness burns like a fire;
By the wrath of the L ord of hosts the land is burned up,
They slice off [in discord] what is on the right hand but are still hungry,
[The tribe of] Manasseh devours [the tribe of his brother] Ephraim, and Ephraim Manasseh,

10.verse_text: Woe (judgment is coming) to those [judges] who issue evil statutes, And to those [magistrates] who constantly record unjust and oppressive decisions, And rob the poor of My people of rightful claims, So that widows may be their spoil And that they may plunder the fatherless. And in the storm of devastation which will come from far away? To whom will you flee for help? And where will you leave your wealth [for safekeeping]? Or fall [dead] among the slain [on the battlefield]. In spite of all this, God’s anger does not turn away, But His hand is still stretched out [in judgment]. The staff in whose hand is My indignation and fury [against Israel’s disobedience]! And commission it against the people of My wrath To take the spoil and to seize the plunder, And to trample them down like mud in the streets. Nor does it plan so in its heart, But instead it is its purpose to destroy And to cut off many nations. Is not Hamath [subdued] like Arpad [her neighbor]? Is not Samaria [in Israel] like Damascus [in Aram]? Whose carved images were greater and more feared than those of Jerusalem and Samaria, Just as I have done to Samaria and her idols?” [declares Assyria]. “I have done this by the power of my [own] hand and by my wisdom, For I have understanding and skill. I have removed the boundaries of the peoples And have plundered their treasures; Like a bull I have brought down those who sat on thrones. And as one gathers eggs that are abandoned, so I have gathered all the earth; And there was not one that flapped its wing, or that opened its beak and chirped.” Is the saw able to magnify itself over the one who wields it? That would be like a club moving those who lift it, Or like a staff raising him who is not [made of] wood [like itself]! And under his glory a fire will be kindled like a burning flame. And it will be as when a sick man wastes away. That a child could write them down. Only a remnant within them will return; The destruction is determined [it is decided and destined for completion], overflowing with justice (righteous punishment). He has passed through Migron [with his army]; At Michmash he stored his equipment. “Geba will be our lodging place for the night.” Ramah trembles, and Gibeah [the city] of Saul has fled. Pay attention, Laishah! Answer her, Anathoth! The inhabitants of Gebim have fled [with their belongings] to safety. He shakes his fist at the mountain of the Daughter of Zion, at the hill of Jerusalem. The tall in stature will be cut down And the lofty will be abased and humiliated. And Lebanon (the Assyrian) will fall by the Mighty One.
So as to deprive the needy of justice
Now what will you do in the day of [God’s] punishment,
Nothing remains but to crouch among the captives
Woe to Assyria, the rod of My anger [against Israel],
I send Assyria against a godless nation
Yet it is not Assyria’s intention [to do My will],
For Assyria says, “Are not my princes all kings?
Is not Calno [conquered] like Carchemish [on the Euphrates]?
As my hand has reached to the kingdoms of the idols,
Shall I not do to Jerusalem and her images

So when the Lord has completed all His work [of judgment] on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, He will say, “I will punish the fruit [the thoughts, the declarations, and the actions] of the arrogant heart of the king of Assyria and the haughtiness of his pride.”
For the Assyrian king has said,
My hand has found the wealth of the people like a nest,
Is the axe able to lift itself over the one who chops with it?
Therefore the Lord, the G od of hosts, will send a wasting disease among the stout warriors of Assyria;
And the Light of Israel will become a fire and His Holy One a flame, And it will burn and devour Assyria’s thorns and briars in a single day.
The Lord will consume the glory of Assyria’s forest and of its fruitful garden, both soul and body,
And the remaining trees of Assyria’s forest will be so few in number
Now in that day the remnant of Israel, and those of the house of Jacob who have escaped, will never again rely on the one who struck them, but will truly rely on the L ord , the Holy One of Israel.
A remnant will return, a remnant of Jacob, to the mighty God.
For though your people, O Israel, may be as the sand of the sea,
For the Lord, the G od of hosts, will execute a complete destruction, one that is decreed, in the midst of all the land.

Therefore, the Lord G od of hosts says this, “O My people who dwell in Zion, do not be afraid of the Assyrian who strikes you with a rod and lifts up his staff against you, as [the king of] Egypt did.
For yet a very little while and My indignation [against you] will be fulfilled and My anger will be directed toward the destruction of the Assyrian.”

The L ord of hosts will brandish a whip against them like the slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb; and His staff will be over the [Red] Sea and He will lift it up the way He did in [the flight from] Egypt.
So it will be in that day, that the burden of the Assyrian will be removed from your shoulders and his yoke from your neck. The yoke will be broken because of the fat.
The Assyrian has come against Aiath [in Judah],
They have gone through the pass, saying,
Cry aloud with your voice [in consternation], O Daughter of Gallim!
Madmenah has fled;
Yet today the Assyrian will halt at Nob [the city of priests];
Listen carefully, the Lord, the G od of hosts, will lop off the [beautiful] boughs with terrifying force;
He will cut down the thickets of the forest with an iron axe,

11.verse_text: Then a Shoot (the Messiah) will spring from the stock of Jesse [David’s father], And a Branch from his roots will bear fruit. The Spirit of wisdom and understanding, The Spirit of counsel and strength, The Spirit of knowledge and of the [reverential and obedient] fear of the L ord — And He will not judge by what His eyes see, Nor make decisions by what His ears hear; And decide with fairness for the downtrodden of the earth; And He shall strike the earth with the rod of His mouth, And with the breath of His lips He shall slay the wicked. And faithfulness the belt around His waist. And the leopard will lie down with the young goat, And the calf and the young lion and the fatted steer together; And a little child will lead them. Their young will lie down together, And the lion shall eat straw like the ox. And the weaned child will put his hand on the viper’s den [and not be hurt]. For the earth will be full of the knowledge of the L ord As the waters cover the sea. The nations will make supplications to the Root of Jesse Who will stand as a signal for the peoples; And His resting place will be glorious. Will again acquire with His hand a second time The remnant of His people, who will remain, From Assyria, from [Lower] Egypt, from Pathros, from Cush (Ethiopia), from Elam [in Persia], from Shinar [Babylonia], from Hamath [in Aram], And from the coastlands bordering the [Mediterranean] Sea. And will gather the dispersed of Judah From the four corners of the earth. Ephraim will not be jealous of Judah, And Judah will not harass Ephraim. Together they will plunder the sons (Arabs) of the east. They will possess Edom and Moab, And the sons of Ammon will be subject to them. And with His scorching wind He will wave His hand over the River; He will strike and divide it into seven channels And make [it possible for] people [to] walk over in sandals. For the remnant of His people who will be left, Just as there was for Israel In the day when they came up out of the land of Egypt.
And the Spirit of the L ord will rest on Him—
And He will delight in the fear of the L ord ,
But with righteousness and justice He will judge the poor,
And righteousness will be the belt around His loins,
And the wolf will dwell with the lamb,
And the cow and the bear will graze [together],
And the nursing child will [safely] play over the hole of the cobra,
They will not hurt or destroy in all My holy mountain,
Then it will happen on that day that the Lord
And He will lift up a signal for the nations And assemble the outcasts of Israel, And those who harass Judah will be cut off; The tongue of the Sea of Egypt;
Then the jealousy of Ephraim will depart,
Ephraim and Judah will [unite and] swoop down on the slopes of the Philistines toward the west;
And the L ord will utterly destroy
And there will be a highway from Assyria

12.verse_text: And on that day you will say, “I will give thanks to You, O L ord ; For though You were angry with me, Your anger has turned away, And You comfort me. I will trust and not be afraid, For the L ord G od is my strength and song; Yes, He has become my salvation.” From the springs of salvation. “Give thanks to the L ord , call on His name [in prayer]. Make His deeds known among the peoples [of the earth]; Proclaim [to them] that His name is exalted!” Let this be known throughout the earth. For great in your midst is the Holy One of Israel.
Therefore with joy you will draw water
And in that day you will say,
Sing praises to the L ord , for He has done excellent and glorious things;
Rejoice and shout for joy, O inhabitant of Zion,

13.verse_text: The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning Babylon which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw [in a prophetic vision]: Summon them [the Medes and Persians] with a loud voice, Wave the [beckoning] hand so that they may enter the doorways of the [Babylonian] nobles. I have even called My great warriors, My proudly exulting ones [the Medes and the Persians who triumph for My honor]— To execute My anger. Like that of many people! A sound of the uproar of the kingdoms, Of nations gathered together! The L ord of hosts is mustering an army for battle. From the end of heaven [the farthest horizon]— The L ord and the weapons of His indignation— To destroy the whole land. And every man’s heart will melt. Pains and anguish will grip them; They will be in pain like a woman in childbirth. They will stare aghast and horrified at one another, Their faces aflame [from the effects of the unprecedented warfare]. Cruel, with wrath and raging anger, To make the land a horror [of devastation]; And He shall exterminate its sinners from it. Will not flash with their light; The sun will be dark when it rises, And the moon will not shed its light. And the wicked for their wickedness [their sin, their injustice, their wrongdoing]; I will also put an end to the arrogance of the proud And will abase the arrogance of the tyrant. And mankind [scarcer] than the pure gold of Ophir. And the earth will be shaken from its place At the wrath of the L ord of hosts In the day of His burning anger. Or like sheep that no man gathers, Each [foreign resident] will turn [and go back] to his own people, And each one flee to his own land. And anyone who is captured will fall by the sword. Before their eyes; Their houses will be looted And their wives ravished. Who have no regard for silver and do not delight in gold [and therefore cannot be bribed]. They will take no pity on the fruit of the womb, Their eyes will not look with compassion on the children. Will be like Sodom and Gomorrah when God overthrew them. Nor will the Arab pitch his tent there, Nor will the shepherds let their sheep lie down there. And their houses will be full of owls; And jackals in their luxurious palaces. Babylon’s time has nearly come, And her days will not be prolonged.
Lift up a signal banner on the bare mountain,
I [the L ord ] have commanded My consecrated ones,
A sound of tumult on the mountains,
They are coming from a distant country,
Wail, for the day of the L ord is at hand! It will come as destruction from the Almighty (All Sufficient One—Invincible God)! Ostriches also will live there, and wild goats will dance there.
Therefore all hands will fall limp,
They [of Babylon] will be shocked and terrified,
Listen carefully, the day of the L ord is coming,
For the stars of heaven and their constellations
In this way I will punish the world for its evil
I will make mortal man more rare than fine gold,
Therefore I will make the heavens tremble;
And like the hunted gazelle,
Anyone who is found will be pierced through,
Their children also will be smashed to pieces
Listen carefully, I will put the Medes [in motion] against them,
Their bows will cut down the young men [of Babylon];
And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldeans’ pride,
Babylon will never be inhabited or lived in from generation to generation;
But desert creatures will lie down there,
Hyenas will howl in their castles,

14.verse_text: For the L ord will have compassion on Jacob (the captives in Babylon) and will again choose Israel, and will settle them in their own land. Foreigners (Gentiles) will join them [as proselytes] and will attach themselves to the house of Jacob (Israel).

The peoples will take them along and bring them to their own place (Judea), and the house of Israel will possess them as an inheritance in the land of the L ord as male and female servants; and they will take captive those whose captives they have been, and they will rule over their [former] oppressors. “How the oppressor has ceased [his insolence], And how the fury has ceased! The scepter of the [tyrant] rulers Which subdued and ruled the nations in wrath with unrelenting persecution. They break into shouts of joy. ‘Since you were laid low, no woodcutter comes up against us.’ It stirs up the spirits of the dead [to greet you], all the leaders of the earth; It raises all the kings of the nations from their thrones [in astonishment at your fall]. ‘You have become as weak as we are. You have become like us. Along with the music of your harps; The maggots [which prey on the dead] are spread out under you [as a bed] And worms are your covering [Babylonian rulers].’ You have been cut down to the ground, You who have weakened the nations [king of Babylon]! ‘I will ascend to heaven; I will raise my throne above the stars of God; I will sit on the mount of assembly In the remote parts of the north. I will make myself like the Most High.’ To the remote recesses of the pit (the region of the dead). They will consider you, saying, ‘Is this the man who made the earth tremble, Who shook kingdoms, And overthrew its cities, Who did not permit his prisoners to return home?’ Each one in his own sepulcher. Like a rejected branch, Clothed with the slain who are pierced by the sword, Who go down to the stones of the pit [into which carcasses are thrown], Like a dead body trampled [underfoot]. Because you have destroyed your land, You have slain your people. May the descendants of evildoers never be named! Because of the wickedness [the sin, the injustice, the wrongdoing] of their fathers. They must not rise and take possession of the earth, And fill the face of the world with cities.” Because the rod [of Judah] that struck you is broken; For out of the serpent’s root will come a viper [King Hezekiah of Judah], And its offspring will be a flying serpent. And the needy will lie down in safety; But I will kill your root with famine, And your survivors will be put to death. Melt away, O Philistia, all of you; For smoke comes out of the north, And there is no straggler in his ranks and no one stands detached [in Hezekiah’s battalions]. That the L ord has founded Zion, And the afflicted of His people will seek and find refuge in it.”
And it will be in the day when the L ord gives you rest from your pain and turmoil and from the harsh service in which you have been enslaved,
that you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon, and say,
The L ord has broken the staff of the wicked,
Which used to strike the peoples in anger with incessant blows,
The whole earth is at rest and is quiet;
Even the cypress trees rejoice over you [kings of Babylon], even the cedars of Lebanon, saying,
Sheol below is excited about you to meet you when you come [you tyrant of Babylon];
All of them will respond [tauntingly] and say to you,
Your pomp and magnificence have been brought down to Sheol,
How you have fallen from heaven, O star of the morning [light-bringer], son of the dawn!
But you said in your heart,
I will ascend above the heights of the clouds;
But [in fact] you will be brought down to Sheol,
Those who see you will gaze at you,
Who made the world like a wilderness
All the kings of the nations, all of them lie [dead] in glorious array,
But you [king of Babylon] have been cast out of your tomb (denied burial)
You will not be united with them in burial,
Prepare a slaughtering place for his sons
“I will rise up against them,” says the L ord of hosts, “and will cut off from Babylon name and survivors, and son and grandson,” declares the L ord .
“I will also make Babylon a possession of the hedgehog and of swamps of water, and I will sweep it away with the broom of destruction,” declares the L ord of hosts.
The L ord of hosts has sworn [an oath], saying, “Just as I have intended, so it has certainly happened, and just as I have planned, so it will stand—

to break the Assyrian in My land, and on My mountains I will trample him underfoot. Then the Assyrian’s yoke will be removed from them (the people of Judah) and his burden removed from their shoulder.
This is the plan [of God] decided for the whole earth [regarded as conquered and put under tribute by Assyria]; and this is the hand [of God] that is stretched out over all the nations.
For the L ord of hosts has decided and planned, and who can annul it? His hand is stretched out, and who can turn it back?”
In the year that King Ahaz [of Judah] died this [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) came:
“Do not rejoice, O Philistia, any of you,
The firstborn of the helpless [of Judah] will feed [on My meadows],
Howl, O gate; cry, O city!
Then what answer will one give the messengers of the [Philistine] nation?

15.verse_text: The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning Moab: Because in a night Ar of Moab is devastated and ruined; Because in a night Kir of Moab is devastated and ruined. Moab wails over Nebo and over Medeba; Everyone’s head is shaved, and every beard is cut off [in mourning]. On their [flat] housetops and in their open squares Everyone is wailing, dissolved in tears. Their voice is heard as far as Jahaz. Therefore the armed men of Moab cry out; Moab’s soul trembles within him. His fugitives are [fleeing] as far as Zoar and Eglath-shelishiyah. For they go up the ascent of Luhith weeping; For on the road to Horonaim they raise a cry of distress over their destruction. Indeed the grass is withered, the new growth dies; There is no green thing. They carry off over the Brook of the Willows. The wailing goes as far as Eglaim and the mournful cry to Beer-elim. Yet I will bring even more woes on Dimon— A lion upon those of Moab who escape and upon the remnant of the land.
They have gone up to the temple and to Dibon, to the high places to weep.
In their streets they have wrapped themselves with sackcloth;
Heshbon and Elealeh [cities claimed by Moab] cry out;
My heart cries out for Moab;
For the waters of Nimrim are desolate.
Therefore the abundance which they have acquired and stored away
For the cry of distress has echoed around the territory of Moab;
For the waters of Dimon are full of blood;

16.verse_text: Send lambs to the ruler of the land [ you Moabites], From Sela [that is, Petra in Edom] through the wilderness to the mountain of the Daughter of Zion (Jerusalem). The daughters of Moab will be at the fords of the [river] Arnon. Cast your shadow [over us] like night in the midst of noon; Hide the outcasts, do not betray the fugitive [to his pursuer]. Be a [sheltered] hiding place to them from the destroyer.” For the extortioner has come to an end, destruction has ceased, Oppressors [who trample men] have completely disappeared from the land, And One will sit on it in faithfulness in the tent (dynasty, family) of David; Judging and seeking justice And being prompt to do righteousness. Even of his arrogance, his conceit, his rage, His untruthful boasting. You will mourn for the raisin cakes of Kir-hareseth, As those who are utterly stricken and discouraged. The lords of the nations have trampled down [Moab’s] choice vine branches, Which reached as far as Jazer and wandered into the wilderness; Its tendrils stretched out, they passed over [the shores of] the [Dead] Sea. I will drench you with my tears, O Heshbon and Elealeh; For the war-cry [of the enemy] has fallen on your summer fruits and your harvest. In the vineyards there will be no singing or joyful sound; No treader treads out wine in the presses, For I (God) put an end to the joyful shouting. And my inner being mourns for Kir-hareseth. When he wearies himself [worshiping] on his high place [of idolatry] And comes to his sanctuary [of Chemosh, god of Moab] to pray, That he will not prevail.
For like wandering birds or scattered nestlings,
[Say to the ruler] “Give us advice, make a decision [for Moab, king of Judah];
Let our outcasts of Moab live among you;
A throne will be established in lovingkindness,
We have heard of the pride of Moab, an excessive pride—
Therefore Moab will wail for Moab; everyone will wail.
For the fields of Heshbon have languished and withered, and the vines of Sibmah as well;
Therefore I (Isaiah) will weep bitterly for Jazer, for the vines of Sibmah.
Gladness and joy are taken away from the fruitful field;
Therefore my heart sounds like a harp [in mournful compassion] for Moab,
So it will come to pass when Moab presents himself,
This is the word which the L ord spoke earlier concerning Moab [when Moab’s pride and resistance to God were first known].

But now the L ord speaks, saying, “Within three years, as the years of a hired man [who will not serve longer than the agreed time], the glory of Moab will be degraded along with all the great population, and the remnant [that survives] will be very small and of no account.”

17.verse_text: The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning Damascus [capital of Aram (Syria), and Israel’s defense against Assyria]. “Listen carefully, Damascus will cease to be a city And will become a fallen ruin. They will be [only a refuge] for flocks to lie down in, And there will be no one to make them afraid. And the kingdom from Damascus And the remnant of Aram (Syria); They will be like the [departed] glory of [her ally] the children of Israel,” Declares the L ord of hosts. And the fatness of his flesh will become lean. As his arm harvests the ears of grain; Yes, it will be like one gleaning ears of grain In the [fertile] Valley of Rephaim. Two or three olives on the topmost branch, Four or five on the [outermost] branches of the fruitful tree,” Declares the L ord , the God of Israel. And his eyes will regard the Holy One of Israel [with awe-inspired reverence]. Nor will he look to that which his fingers have made, Neither the Asherim (symbols of the goddess Asherah) nor the incense altars. Or like branches which they abandoned before the children of Israel; And the land will be a desolation. And have not remembered the Rock of your Stronghold— And set the grounds with vine slips of a strange god, And in the morning you bring your seed to blossom; Yet [promising as it is] the harvest will be a heap [of ruins that passes away] In the day of sickness and incurable pain. Who roar like the roaring of the seas, And the noise of nations Who roar like the rumbling of mighty waters! But God will rebuke them and they will flee far away, And be chased like chaff on the mountains before the wind, Or like whirling dust before the storm. This is the portion (fate) of those who plunder us, And the lot of those who pillage us.
The cities of Aroer [east of the Jordan] are deserted;
The fortified city will disappear from Ephraim,
“Now in that day the [former] glory of Jacob [Israel—his might, his population, his prosperity] will fade,
And it will be like the reaper gathering the standing grain,
Yet gleanings will be left in the land [of Israel] like the shaking of the olive tree,
In that day man will have regard for his Maker,
And he will not have regard for the [idolatrous] altars, the work of his hands,
In that day the strong cities of Aram and Israel will be like deserted places in the forest,
Because you [Judah] have forgotten the God of your salvation Therefore you plant lovely plants Before morning the Assyrians are no more.
In the day that you plant it you carefully fence it in,
Oh, the uproar of many peoples
The nations roar on like the roaring of many waters,
At evening time, now look, sudden terror!

18.verse_text: Woe (judgment is coming) to the land of whirring wings Which is beyond the rivers of Cush (Ethiopia), To the place [of worship] of the name of the L ord of hosts, to Mount Zion [in Jerusalem]. Even in vessels of papyrus on the surface of the waters. Go, swift messengers, to a nation [of people] tall and smooth (clean shaven), To a people feared far and wide, A powerful and oppressive nation Whose land the rivers divide. When a banner is raised on the mountains, you will see it! When a trumpet is blown, you will hear it! “I will be quiet and I will look on from My dwelling place, Like shimmering heat above the sunshine, Like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.” And the flower becomes a ripening grape, He will cut off the sprigs [without buds] with pruning knives, And [He will] remove and cut away the spreading branches. And for the beasts of the earth; And the birds of prey will [spend the] summer feeding on them, And all the beasts of the earth will spend harvest time on them. From a people tall and smooth (clean shaven), From a people feared far and wide, A powerful and oppressive nation, Whose land the rivers divide—
Which sends ambassadors by the sea,
All you inhabitants of the world, you who dwell on the earth,
For this is what the L ord has said to me,
For before the harvest, when the blossom is over
They (warriors) will be left together for the mountain birds of prey,
At that time a gift of homage will be brought to the L ord of hosts

19.verse_text: The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning Egypt: Listen carefully, the L ord is riding on a swift cloud and is about to come to Egypt; The idols of Egypt will tremble at His presence, And the heart of the Egyptians will melt within them. And they will fight, each one against his brother and each one against his neighbor, City against city, kingdom against kingdom. And I will confuse their strategy, So that they will consult the idols and the spirits of the dead, And mediums and soothsayers. And a mighty king will rule over them,” declares the Lord G od of hosts. And the river will be parched and dry. The streams of Egypt will thin out and dry up, The reeds and the rushes will rot away. And all the sown fields of the Nile Will become dry, be blown away, and be no more. And all those who cast a hook into the Nile will mourn, And those who spread nets upon the waters will languish. And those who weave white cloth will be ashamed. And all those who work for wages will be grieved in soul. The counsel of the Pharaoh’s wisest advisors has become stupid. How can you say to Pharaoh, “I am a son of the wise, a son of ancient kings?” Please let them tell you, And let them understand what the L ord of hosts Has purposed against Egypt [if they can]. The princes of Memphis are deluded [and entertain false hope]; Those who are the cornerstone of her tribes Have led Egypt astray. Her leaders have caused Egypt to stagger in all that she does, As a drunken man staggers in his vomit. Which head or tail, [high] palm branch or [low] bulrush, may do.
“So I will provoke Egyptians against Egyptians;
Then the spirit of the Egyptians will become exhausted within them and emptied out;
And I will hand over the Egyptians to a hard and cruel master,
The waters from the sea will dry up,
The canals will become foul-smelling,
The meadows by the Nile, by the edge of the Nile,
The fishermen will lament (cry out in grief),
Moreover, those who make linen from combed flax
[Those who are] the pillars and foundations of Egypt will be crushed;
The princes of Zoan are complete fools;
Where then are your wise men?
The princes of Zoan have acted like fools,
The L ord has mixed a spirit of distortion within her;
There will be no work for Egypt
In that day the Egyptians will become like [helpless] women, and they will tremble and be frightened because of the waving of the hand of the L ord of hosts, which He is going to wave over them.

The land of Judah [Assyria’s ally] will become a terror to the Egyptians; everyone to whom Judah is mentioned will be in dread of it, because of the purpose of the L ord of hosts which He is planning against Egypt.
In that day five cities in the land of Egypt will speak the language of [the Hebrews of] Canaan and swear allegiance to the L ord of hosts. One [of them] will be called the City of Destruction.
In that day there will be an altar to the L ord in the midst of the land of Egypt, and a memorial stone to the L ord near its border.

It will become a sign and a witness to the L ord of hosts in the land of Egypt; for they will cry to the L ord because of oppressors, and He will send them a Savior, a [Great] Defender, and He will rescue them.

And so the L ord will make Himself known to Egypt, and the Egyptians will know [heed, honor, and cherish] the L ord in that day. They will even worship with sacrifices [of animals] and offerings [of produce]; they will make a vow to the L ord and fulfill it.
The L ord will strike Egypt, striking but healing it; so they will return to the L ord , and He will respond to them and heal them.

In that day there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrians will come into Egypt and the Egyptians into Assyria; and the Egyptians will worship and serve [the L ord ] with the Assyrians.
In that day Israel will be the third party with Egypt and with Assyria [in a Messianic league], a blessing in the midst of the earth,
whom the L ord of hosts has blessed, saying, “Blessed is Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel My heritage.”

20.verse_text: In the year that the Tartan [the Assyrian commander in chief] came to Ashdod [in Philistia], when Sargon king of Assyria sent him and he fought against Ashdod and captured it,

at that time the L ord spoke through Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, “Go, untie the sackcloth from your hips and take your sandals off your feet.” And he did so, walking around stripped [to his loincloth] and barefoot.
And the L ord said, “Even as My servant Isaiah has walked stripped and barefoot for three years as a sign and forewarning concerning Egypt and Cush (Ethiopia),
in the same way the king of Assyria will lead away the Egyptian captives and the Cushite exiles, young and old, stripped and barefoot, even with buttocks uncovered—to the shame of Egypt.
Then they will be dismayed and ashamed because of Cush their hope and Egypt their boast.

So the inhabitants of this coastland [the Israelites and their neighbors] will say in that day, ‘Look what has happened to those in whom we hoped and trusted and to whom we fled for help to be spared from the king of Assyria! But we, how will we escape [captivity and exile]?’ ”

21.verse_text: The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning the Desert of the Sea (the seasonally flooded plains just south of Babylon): As windstorms in the Negev (the South) sweep through, So it (God’s judgment) comes from the desert, from [the hostile armies of] a terrifying land. The treacherous one deals treacherously, and the destroyer destroys. Go up, Elam! Lay siege, Media! All the groaning [caused by Babylon’s ruthless oppressions] I [the L ord ] have brought to an end. Pains have seized me like the pains of a woman in childbirth; I am so bent and bewildered that I cannot hear, I am so terrified that I cannot see. “Rise up, captains [of Belshazzar’s court], oil your shields [for battle, for your enemy is at the gates]!” “Go, station the lookout, let him report what he sees. A train of donkeys and a train of camels, Let him pay attention and listen closely, very closely.” “O Lord, I stand continually on the watchtower by day, And I am stationed every night at my guard post. And one said, “Fallen, fallen is Babylon; And all the carved images of her gods are shattered on the ground.” What I have heard from the L ord of hosts, The God of Israel, I have [joyfully] announced to you [that Babylon is to fall]. Someone keeps calling to me from Seir (Edom), “Watchman, what is left of the night [of Assyrian oppression]? Watchman, what is left of the night? [How long until morning?]” “The morning comes [only briefly], but also [comes] the night [of Babylonian oppression]. If you would ask [of me then], ask [again, if Edom really wishes to know]; Come back again.” In the thickets of Arabia you must spend the night, Caravans of Dedanites. O inhabitants of the land of Tema [in Arabia]; Meet the fugitive with bread. From the drawn sword, from the bent bow And from the press of battle and grief of war.
A harsh vision has been shown to me;
Therefore [continues Isaiah] my loins are filled with anguish;
My mind reels, horror overwhelms me; The twilight I longed for has been turned into fear and trembling for me.
They set the table [for the doomed banquet], they spread out the cloth, they eat, they drink;
This is what the Lord says to me,
When he sees a chariot, horsemen in pairs,
And the lookout called like a lion,
Now look! Here comes a troop of riders, horsemen in pairs.”
O my threshed people [Judah, who must be judged and trampled down by Babylon], my afflicted of the threshing floor.
The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning Dumah (Edom):
The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning Arabia:
For they have fled from the swords,
For the Lord has said this to me, “Within a year, according to the years of a hired man [who will work no longer than was agreed], all the splendor of [the tribe of] Kedar will end;
and the remainder of the number of archers, the mighty men of the sons of Kedar, will be few; for the L ord , the God of Israel, has spoken.”

22.verse_text: The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning the Valley of Vision: What is the matter with you now, that you have all gone up to the housetops, A tumultuous city, a joyous and exuberant city; Your slain were not slain [in a glorious death] with the sword, Nor did they die in battle. And have been captured without the bow [which they had thrown away]; All of you who were found were taken captive together, Though they had fled far away. Let me weep bitterly. Do not try to comfort me over the destruction of the daughter of my people.” In the Valley of Vision, A [day of] breaking down walls And a crying [for help] to the mountain. With the chariots, infantry and horsemen; And Kir uncovered the shield. And the horsemen took their fixed positions [in an offensive array] at the gate [of Jerusalem]. And in that day you looked to the weapons of the House of the Forest (Solomon’s armory). In the wall of the City of David [the citadel of Zion] were many; You collected [within the city’s walls] the waters of the Lower Pool (Siloam). And you tore down the houses [to get materials] to fortify the city wall [by extending it]. But you did not look to its Maker, Nor did you recognize Him who planned it long ago. To shaving the head and to wearing sackcloth [in humiliation]. Killing of oxen and slaughtering of sheep, Eating meat and drinking wine, saying, “Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we may die.” “This sin absolutely will not be forgiven you Until you die,” says the Lord G od of hosts. And whom do you have here, That you have hewn out a tomb here for yourself, You who hew a sepulcher on the height, You who carve a resting place for yourself in the rock? And He is about to grasp you firmly And toss you into a vast country; There you will die And there your splendid chariots will be, You shame of your master’s house.’ And you will be pulled down from your position [of importance]. That I will summon My servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah. And tie your sash securely around him. I will entrust him with your authority; He will become a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah. When he opens no one will shut, When he shuts no one will open. And he will become a throne of honor and glory to his father’s house.
You [Jerusalem] who were full of noise,
All your leaders have fled together [with your king],
Therefore I say, “Look away from me;
For the Lord G od of hosts has a day of panic and of tumult, of trampling, of confusion
Elam took up the quiver
And it came to pass that your choicest valleys were full of chariots,
Then God removed the [protective] covering of Judah;
You saw that the breaches
Then you counted the houses of Jerusalem
You also made a reservoir between the two walls For the waters of the Old Pool, To Shebna, who is in charge of the royal household [but is building himself a tomb worthy of a king, and say to him],
Therefore in that day the Lord G od of hosts called you to weeping, to mourning,
Instead, there is joy and jubilation,
But the L ord of hosts revealed Himself in my ears,
For the Lord G od of hosts says this, “Go to this [contemptible] steward,
‘What business do you have here?
Listen carefully, the L ord is about to hurl you away violently, O man;
And roll you up tightly like a ball
I will depose you from your office,
Then it will come to pass in that day
And I will clothe him with your tunic [of distinction]
Then I will set on his shoulder the key of the house of David;
I will drive him like a peg in a firm place,

So they will hang on him all the honor and glory [the complete responsibility] of his father’s house, offspring and issue [of the family, high and low], all the least of the articles, from the bowls to all the jars.

In that day,” declares the L ord of hosts, “the peg (Eliakim) that was driven into the firm place will give way; it will even break off and fall, and the burden hanging on it will be cut off, for the L ord has spoken.”

23.verse_text: The [mournful, inspired] oracle ( a burden to be carried) concerning Tyre: Wail, O ships of Tarshish, For Tyre is destroyed, without house, without harbor; It is reported to them from the land of Cyprus (Kittim). And she was the market of nations. For the sea speaks, the stronghold of the sea, saying, “I have neither labored nor given birth [to children]; I have neither brought up young men nor reared virgins.” They will be in agony at the report about Tyre. Wail, O inhabitants of the coastland [of Tyre]. Whose origin dates back to antiquity, Whose feet used to carry her [far away] to colonize distant places? Whose merchants were princes, whose traders were the honored of the earth? To bring into contempt and humiliation all the honored of the earth. There is no more restraint [on you to make you pay tribute to Tyre]. He has shaken the kingdoms; The L ord has given a command concerning Canaan to destroy her strongholds and her fortresses [like Tyre and Sidon]. Arise, cross over to Cyprus; even there you will find no rest.” For your stronghold [of Tyre] is destroyed. O forgotten prostitute; Play the strings skillfully, sing many songs, That you may be remembered.
Be silent, you inhabitants of the coastland, You merchants of Sidon; Your messengers crossed the sea The grain of the Shihor, the harvest of the Nile River, was Tyre’s revenue;
And they were on great waters.
Be ashamed, O Sidon [mother-city of Tyre, now like a widow bereaved of her children];
Cross over to Tarshish [to seek safety as exiles];
Who has planned this against Tyre, the bestower of crowns,
The L ord of hosts has planned it, to defile the pride of all beauty,
Overflow your land like [the overflow of] the Nile, O Daughter of Tarshish;
He has stretched out His hand over the sea,
He has said, “You shall never again exult [in triumph], O crushed Virgin Daughter of Sidon.

Now look at the land of the Chaldeans (Babylonia)—this is the people which was not; the Assyrians allocated Tyre for desert creatures—they set up their siege towers, they stripped its palaces, they made it a ruin.
Now in that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, like the days of one king. At the end of seventy years it will happen to Tyre as in the prostitute’s song:
Take a harp, walk around the city,

It will come to pass at the end of seventy years that the L ord will remember Tyre. Then she will return to her prostitute’s wages and will play the [role of a] prostitute [by trading] with all the kingdoms on the face of the earth.

But her commercial gain and her prostitute’s wages will be dedicated to the L ord ; it will not be treasured or stored up, but her commercial gain will become sufficient food and stately clothing for those who dwell (minister) in the presence of the L ord .

24.verse_text: Behold, the L ord lays waste to the earth, devastates it, twists and distorts its face and scatters its inhabitants.

And the people will be like the priest, the servant like his master, the maid like her mistress, the buyer like the seller, the lender like the borrower, the creditor like the debtor [as God’s impartial judgment of sin comes on all].
The earth will be completely laid waste and utterly pillaged, for the L ord has spoken this word.
The earth dries up and crumbles away, the world dries out and crumbles away, the exalted of the people of the earth fade away.
The earth also is polluted by its inhabitants, because they have transgressed laws, violated statutes, and broken the everlasting covenant.

Therefore, a curse devours the earth, and those who live on it suffer the punishment of their guilt. Therefore, the inhabitants of the earth are burned [under the curse of God’s wrath], and few people are left. The vine decays; All the merry-hearted sigh and groan. The noise of those who rejoice ends, The joy of the harp ceases. Strong drink is bitter to those who drink it. Every house is shut up so that no one may enter. All jubilation is darkened, The joy of the earth is banished. And the gate is battered into ruins. As the shaking of an olive tree, As the gleanings when the grape harvest is over [and only a little of the fruit remains]. They rejoice from the [Mediterranean] Sea in the majesty of the L ord . The name of the L ord , the God of Israel [honor His name], In the coastlands and islands of the [Mediterranean] Sea. But I say, “I waste away, I waste away. Woe to me! The treacherous deal treacherously, Indeed, the treacherous deal very treacherously.” Confront you, O inhabitant of the earth. And he who comes up out of the pit will be caught in the snare; For the windows of heaven are opened, and the foundations of the earth tremble. The earth is split apart, The earth is shaken violently. And sways like a shack; Its transgression lies heavily upon it, And it will fall and not rise again. That the L ord will visit and punish the host (fallen angels) of heaven on high, And the kings of the earth on the earth. As prisoners [are gathered] in a dungeon; They will be shut up in prison, And after many days they will be visited and punished. For the L ord of hosts will reign on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem, And His glory and brilliance will shine before His elders.
The new wine mourns,
The mirth of the timbrels (tambourines) ceases,
They do not drink wine with a song;
The city of chaos is broken down;
There is an outcry in the streets concerning the wine;
Horrible desolation is left in the city,
For so it will be in the midst of the earth among the peoples,
They [who have escaped and remain] raise their voices, they shout for joy;
Therefore honor and glorify the L ord in the east [in the region of light],
From the ends of the earth we hear songs, “Glory and honor to the Righteous One,”
Terror and pit [of destruction] and snare
Then it will be that he who flees at the sound of terror will fall into the pit,
The earth is broken completely apart,
The earth reels back and forth like a drunkard
So it will happen in that day
They will be gathered together
Then the full moon will be embarrassed and the sun ashamed,

25.verse_text: O L ord , You are my God; I will exalt You, I will praise and give thanks to Your name; For You have done miraculous things, Plans formed long, long ago, [fulfilled] with perfect faithfulness. A fortified city into a ruin; It will never be rebuilt. Cities of terrible and violent nations will fear You. A stronghold for the poor in his distress, A shelter from the storm, a shade from the heat; For the breath of tyrants Is like a rainstorm against a wall. A banquet of aged wines—choice pieces [flavored] with marrow, Of refined, aged wines. And the veil [of death] that is woven and spread over all the nations. And the Lord G od will wipe away tears from all faces, And He will take away the disgrace of His people from all the earth; For the L ord has spoken. “Indeed, this is our God for whom we have waited that He would save us. This is the L ord for whom we have waited; Let us shout for joy and rejoice in His salvation.” And Moab will be trampled down in his place As straw is trampled down in the [filthy] water of a manure pile. As a swimmer spreads out his hands to swim, But the Lord will humiliate his pride in spite of the [skillful] movements of his hands. Lay low, and cast to the ground, to the dust.
For You have made a city into a heap [of trash], A palace of foreigners is no longer a city, Like heat in the shadow of a cloud, the song of the tyrants is silenced.
Therefore a strong people will honor You;
For You have been a stronghold for the helpless,
Like heat in a dry land, You will subdue the noise of foreigners [rejoicing over their enemies];
On this mountain [Zion] the L ord of hosts will prepare a lavish banquet for all peoples [to welcome His reign on earth],
And on this mountain He will destroy the covering that is [cast] over all peoples,
He will swallow up death [and abolish it] for all time.
It will be said in that day,
For the hand of the L ord will rest on this mountain [Zion],
And Moab will spread out his hands in the middle of the filth
The high fortifications of your walls He will bring down,

26.verse_text: In that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah: “We have a strong city; He sets up salvation as walls and ramparts. Because he trusts and takes refuge in You [with hope and confident expectation]. For the L ord G od is an everlasting Rock [the Rock of Ages]. He lays it low, He lays it low to the ground, He hurls it to the dust. Even the feet of the suffering, and the steps of the helpless.” O Upright One, make a level path for the just and righteous. We have waited expectantly for You; Your name, even Your memory, is the desire and deep longing of our souls. Indeed, my spirit within me seeks You diligently; For [only] when Your judgments are experienced on the earth Will the inhabitants of the world learn righteousness. He does not learn righteousness; In the land of uprightness he deals unjustly, And refuses to see the majesty of the L ord . Let them see Your zeal for Your people and be put to shame; Indeed, let the fire reserved for Your enemies consume them. Since You have also performed for us all that we have done. But through You alone we confess Your name. Therefore You have punished and destroyed them, And You have wiped out every memory of them [every trace of them]. You have increased the nation, You are glorified; You have extended all the borders of the land. They managed only a prayerful whisper When Your discipline was upon them.
